newsitem.title: GABON: Brazzaville warring parties in Gabon for talks.
newsitem.headline: Brazzaville warring parties in Gabon for talks.

text.p: Envoys from Congo Republic President Pascal Lissouba arrived in Gabon on Thursday for talks aimed at ending over a month of political and ethnic bloodshed in their capital Brazzaville, officials said.
Sources close to Gabon's presidency said talks would begin in the capital Libreville late on Thursday or Friday. A U.N. source said Friday was more likely.

Residents in Brazzaville told Reuters by telephone that a fragile truce there was holding but said fighters from both sides were looting in areas under their control -- with hitherto untouched administrative buildings a target.
"Each side is finishing off the looting of the district under its control," one said.
Gabon's veteran president, Omar Bongo, is spearheading international mediation efforts with U.N. and Organisation of African Unity special envoy Mohamed Sahnoun.
Envoys of former military leader Denis Sassou Nguesso, Lissouba's rival and predecessor, arrived on Wednesday.
Shooting broke out in Brazzaville on Wednesday night but state radio there reported that rival fighters had met to bury the hatchet -- suggesting a celebration of peace progress.
The radio, heard across the river in Kinshasa after over 40 minutes of sustained shellfire and other shooting, spoke of reconciliation. Brazzaville state television showed the two sides fraternising.

The conflict began after soldiers surrounded Sassou's home as part of a crackdown on private militia ahead of a now postponed July 27 presidential election. Of numerous truces in the showdown none has been strictly adhered to.
Sahnoun says the aim of talks is to enable a presidential election to be held within the next two months. Plans for a U.N.-sponsored mainly African peace force are taking shape.
Medical workers say the clashes have killed hundreds of people in the capital of the oil-producing former French colony, many of them civilians.
